DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court To Hear Appeal In Landlord Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court has agreed to hear the appeal of a landlord accused of discrimination for denying housing to an unmarried couple. ``As I see it, this is one of the most important First Amendment issues in the country,'' said James Anderson, attorney for landlord Layle French. Anderson argues that some forms of discrimination ``are good.'' ``I'm very encouraged by the Supreme Court agreeing to hear the case,'' Anderson said Monday. French, 33, was fined $1,048 in June by an administrative law judge who decided he violated the state's anti-discrimination law when he reneged on an agreement he made in February 1988 to rent his house in Marshall to Sue Parsons. Parsons had said she intended to live in the house with her fiance, and French later decided that would be against his religion. The couple now are married. French is a member of the Marshall Evangelical Free Church, an independent Christian church. The state Court of Appeals rejected French's appeal. Anderson said the Appeals Court panel ruled that the state's compelling interest to eliminate discrimination was enough to override French's religious belief. ``The court of appeals didn't go far enough,'' Anderson said. ``You have to look at the sort of discrimination. If it's discrimination against race, or women, or a physical handicap, then yes, religion should not override those. ``But other forms of discrimination are good. Layle is discriminating against what many people view as immoral.'' Stephen Cooper, the state commissioner of Human Rights, said French overlooks the fact that his action violated Parsons' religious freedom. ``The biggest threat here is Mr. French imposing his religious beliefs on tenants,'' Cooper said. ``He stands for the lack of religious freedom. That's exactly what we fled the rest of the world for 200 years ago.'' Peter Popovich, chief justice of the state Supreme Court, said he did not know when the case would come up.
